Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineered Protein Complexes for Designable Control over Metabolic Pathway Flux

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Microbes can be engineered with new and/or modified metabolic pathways to make a wide variety of compounds, including flavors and fragrances, therapeutics, plastics, and biofuels. This project aims to investigate the manner in which engineered protein assemblies within living cells can improve the sustainable production of these desirable chemicals. Scaffolded protein assemblies are built using modular protein-protein interaction parts, which act to co-localize enzymes of a given pathway, forming a complex structure that more efficiently catalyzes the chemical reactions involved in production. The use of modular parts provides programmable control over the structure, though currently the resulting changes in product formation are not predictable. However, the modular nature of this system will allow for facile manipulation of key architectural features to test hypotheses and determine the critical design principles for functional assembly and increased production. Understanding the fundamental rules governing protein scaffolding and its effects on production should considerably improve our ability to apply this strategy to new pathways and products.

Broader impacts
Outreach activities have been designed to introduce synthetic biology research to the broader educational community. The international Genetically Engineered Machines (iGEM) competition will be the core outreach platform. This annual summer-long program will involve a team of Berkeley undergraduates, prospective community college transfers, and both an in- and a pre-service high school teacher. The team will be guided by intensive peer and senior mentorship in a working synthetic biology lab; thus upon completion they will be empowered with the ability to conduct independent research. A far greater number of students will be indirectly influenced through the participating high school teachers, who will use their experiences in the program to better mentor their students and inspire and nurture interest in careers in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Compartmentalization of metabolic pathways has the potential to increase the efficiency of flux for the production of desired products in microbial fermentations. Previous research by my lab and others has demonstrated that synthetic assemblies of enzymes can provide improvements; however, the design principles determining how these assemblies can achieve these gains is not well understood. In this project, we engineered synthetic protein scaffolds where we have maximum control over the design. We determined several complications with these relatively simple designs, including internal ribosome binding sites resulting in expression of unintended truncated scaffold molecules and the likely production of large assemblies through multimerization due to the scaffolded enzymes being oligomers (i.e., dimers and tetramers). Based on this work, we hypothesize that the most important parameter for increased compartmentalization-based flux is enzyme stoichiometry. Specifically, increased copies of a limiting enzyme surrounding the upstream enzyme should resultantly increase the probability for a productive collision compared to simple diffusion. To achieve a high stoichiometry of enzyme in a programmable manner, we developed a synthetic adaptor strategy to programmably co-assemble multiple scaffolded assemblies. Using this strategy, we have successfully produced extremely protein-rich compartments that can partition targeted enzymes both in vitro and in vivo.

 

As a broader impact, I have used team-based research as a means for providing a deep research experience to a diverse group of undergraduates. The primary premise for this approach is that peer-to-peer mentorship is often extremely effective given a concrete challenge as well as providing a support structure for undergraduates new to research or lacking a strong pre-existing support structure. Towards this, we initially started with international Genetically Engineered Machines (iGEM) teams and have continued with similar team-based research going into more depth on a single research topic in an effort we call Special Projects in Synthetic Biology (SPSB). The teams have one or two graduate student mentors and meet periodically with myself. We endeavor to push a project to sufficient depth to publish and the students annually present their findings in campus and conferences. In this manner, the students obtain an experience as close to the graduate school experience as possible. Accordingly, students who have graduated have gone on to prestigious graduate schools, start-up companies, founding companies, and medical school. Importantly, each student feel confident in their informed choices based on their intensive research experience in iGEM or SPSB.
